definitions.definition: to find or discover somebody/something by looking carefully for them/it

examples.text: We finally traced him to an address in Chicago.
I have been unable to trace the letter you mentioned.
The stolen paintings have been successfully traced to a London warehouse.
Police are anxious to trace the owners of a car parked near the scene.

definitions.definition: to find the origin or cause of something

examples.text: She could trace her family tree back to the 16th century.
The leak was eventually traced to a broken seal.
The police traced the call *(= used special electronic equipment to find out who made the phone call)* to her ex-husband's number.
The origins of the custom are difficult to trace.
Words have over the centuries acquired meanings not easily traced in dictionaries.

definitions.definition: to describe a process or the development of something

examples.text: Her book traces the town's history from Saxon times to the present day.

definitions.definition: to draw a line or lines on a surface

examples.text: She traced a line in the sand.

definitions.definition: to follow the shape or outline of something

examples.text: He traced the route on the map.
A tear traced a path down her cheek.
She lightly traced the outline of his face with her finger.

definitions.definition: to copy a map, drawing, etc. by drawing on tracing paper (= paper that you can see through) placed over it

wordOrigin: verb Middle English (first recorded as a noun in the sense ‘path that someone or something takes’): from Old French trace (noun), tracier (verb), based on Latin tractus ‘drawing, draught’, from trahere ‘draw, pull’.
